Yes, the Palace of Versailles witnessed some notorious incidents during its time as a royal residence. One of the most significant was the October Days, which occurred in 1789 during the French Revolution. A large mob of angry French citizens stormed the palace in protest against the high cost of food and the lack of political power held by the people. The mob ransacked the palace and forced the royal family to flee to Paris, effectively ending the reign of the French monarchy.

Another notorious incident was the attempt on the life of Louis XV in 1757 by a man named Robert-François Damiens. Damiens, who resented the monarchy and the aristocracy, attacked the king with a knife during a public ceremony at Versailles. Although the king was injured, he survived the attack, and Damiens was subsequently executed in a gruesome manner.

Additionally, the court at Versailles was known for intrigue and betrayal, and many courtiers vied for power and influence. There were also many rumors and scandals related to the personal lives of the royal family, including affairs and illegitimate children.

Despite these incidents, the Palace of Versailles remains a symbol of French history and culture and attracts millions of visitors every year who come to admire its grandeur and learn about its fascinating history.
